number of helpful: 20 of 23 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Want to play with friends and survive in a zombie apocalypse?  Then L4D2 is a game for you! I always had fun with a friend when playing online and it's easy to create your own lobby. Noteworthy, the more friends playing, the better. Having the  Director avaliable to change the gameplay everytime you play also helps to make sure the game doesn't becoming too boring. You can also crank up the difficulty for a challenge (be warned though that if you're playing in expert mode, bring 3 other friends)! One issue I had with this game were the origin of the weapons (in other words, the way the weapons were held). The original game was fine but now, they're too centered in the screen and/or take up too much space (like the hunting rifle). However, this issue can be "fixed" in the workshop by downloading custom content and there's even an add-on that re-origins the default weapons. If you cannot find something in the workshop that you want/like, don't worry as it's very easy to install custom add-ons (from other websites) through the L4D2 file directories. There is another problem I keep facing when playing online in public lobbies. Some players should have practiced more and adjusted to the game by playing offline but instead, they decided to rush in and don't provide too much help due to their lack of experience. Sometimes, there are trolls too and it may be necessary to kick them. The worst issue I had was versus in which players kept on leaving after dying as survivors. Still, this is a good game to play with friends and I recommend it.

number of helpful: 20 of 24 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												One of my favourite games ever. 9/10.Great multi-player co-op game that still has a ton of replay value, six years later. Where it really shines is in Versus mode, where teams play against each other, taking turns playing as the Special Infected.  Left 4 Dead 2 is simply a must-have for all survival horror enthusiasts. The new game modes and the usual mix of adrenaline and co-op gameplay is the living(dead) proof that a sequel doesn’t always have to change its original nature to be enjoyable, very enjoyable!Before playing Versus mode, however, make sure you have played through Campaign mode completely at least once. Of course, story is for single player games, and L4D2 certainly isn't that. To get the most out of the game, you need to play it with three other people, especially on higher difficulties where the AI companions are all but useless. They'll do a good enough job at shooting zombies, but often get sidetracked at killing a few straggling common infected, while your busy fighting a Tank. Or, they'll continually shout "We need to stick together!" when you try and keep moving, but they just won't follow you. The most frustrating is during the game's gauntlet events, where you have to go and turn off something like an alarm, and the AI just won't keep up. If you don't have access to Xbox Live, Steam then L4D2 will get old really quick. I have played the game for over 500 hours on Steam. I have also played the game for 100 hours on Xbox. So I do have enough time to make a review on the game. With friends, the game is still a blast. The AI Director returns, and again changes the maps according to how well you are doing. If you're full on ammo and health packs, prepare to meet up with a host of special infected. Be on the verge of death with only a frying pan, however, and you won't face quite as many. And nothing is as exhilarating as going into a room to find a pipe bomb in one game, and trying to grab it in another game only to find a Witch sobbing in the corner.Versus mode returns, and is still the most fun of the bunch. In the eight player mode, four people are survivors, and four are the infected. All of the special infected return from the first game, including the repulsive Boomer, the ferocious Tank, and the creepy Smoker. Three new infected join the roster this time around, and fit in just great. The Charger is able to pick up a survivor, carry them, and pummel them into the ground. The Spitter spits deadly poison that lingers on the ground. And the Jockey can jump on a survivors back, steering them into danger zones such as fire or a Spitter's poison patch. Each type of special infected are unique and fun, and the addition of three more is just icing on the cake. Like the first game, playing as the special infected is still a blast - there's nothing quite like setting up an ambush with your fellow zombies to kill the survivors in Versus mode.Survival mode makes another appearance as well. Released as DLC in the first game, it comes to L4D2 mostly unchanged, having the four survivors face waves of endless infected coming to save them, with rescue never coming. It's fun.The environments are much more detailed and atmospheric. The rain effects are especially mind-blowing, and can make the threat of an oncoming zombie assault quite stressful when you can't see five feet in front of your face. The ways in which zombies die are also gruesomely spectacular. With the introduction of melee weapons, you can hack at certain body parts of the infected, taking off a leg, chunk of head, or outright decapitating them. Bullets also tear off flesh to reveal ribcages, and chainsaws literally rip the infected apart. There are some nagging clipping issues, such as having zombies' heads protrude through walls, or being able to walk through your allies.The sound direction is stellar, from the powerful gun shots to the creepy, ambient groans and moans warning you of nearby special infected. The soundtrack is fitting for the American South, but could've been longer, as it repeats itself too often. Though the core gameplay remains pretty much the same, there is more than enough new content and improved action to make this zombie apocalypse highly recommendable.The fact that there are addons makes the game even more enjoyable. Oh. One negative thing? I am seriously getting fed up with most of the L4D2 public community. Just blocked my 40th person, they spent the past two hours trash talking everyone on my team with horrible insults and claiming that we all hack (all because I shot a noisy boomer through a wall). People who join, suicide, then leave. Who accuse others of hacking. Who call "RAGE" every time someone leaves. Who blame the server for every failure. Who swap while people are still loading in, resulting in the affected player getting kicked by the swappers team.Oh and don't even get me started on the "competitive" players... (not to generalize... bad apples, you know...)It's not very often you get to meet nice, kind, great teamplayers. But once you do, it's a blast! Search for groups who focuses on having fun rather than winning.  It's worthwile. Trust me. Slash and hack!

content:
Posted: April 17, 2011
												While L4D2 improves upon the original in many meaningful ways, it fails to recapture the same magic.While I was never one of those people who threw their arms in protest when L4D2  was announced, I was nonetheless a bit skeptical as to whether or not a fully fledged sequel, After spending time with L4D2, I can with no uncertainty say that this game is indeed a true sequel, as opposed to a glorified expansion pack. The sequel not only provides a new setting (one with more character when compared to the original), new characters, new weapons and new enemies, but entirely new gameplay mechanics. It feels fresh and new and yet at the same time, comfortingly familiar.L4D2 is an improvement over the original in almost every aspect. But it fails somewhat in one major aspect, it just doesn't feel as magical or expertly crafted as its predecessor.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												More than 4 years after its release, this is still one of the very best (if not the best) co-operative FPS shooter, where teamwork is highly emphasized but you are also given complete freedom at doing whatever you want, although if you want to succeed easily in the missions, you will learn to enjoy and appreciate constant communication with your teammates. The concept of the game has been clearly very well thought-out and over 400 hours later, i am still drawn to play this game and it never gets old. The campaign missions are great to familiarize yourself with the maps, the settings, the gameplay, the different infected and their distinctive attacks. Everything balances itself out at every turn. But the real strength of this game is its multiplayer. You simply cannot experience the full force of Left 4 Dead, without having played its many multiplayer modes. There are so many different game possibilities and different objectives. It is one of the very few games that can keep me going for several hours, irrespective if i'm tired or sleepy - the adrenaline rush just keeps me awake and the feeling of satisfaction if you work well as a team is simply tremendous.There are also private game servers which offer even more customizable game modes. The standard versus mode for the official game is 4 vs 4. But on third-party servers, you will encounter 10 vs 10, which changes the game by enabling more chaos and way more fun. I highly recommend that you try it if you ever get tired of the official game modes and want to try something new and even more exciting.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												Alright, I think I'm finally due for a review...Back in 2008, Left 4 Dead caught my eye.  The idea of zombies, (How original, amirite, although It was a bit newer back then.) slicing their heads off, blowing off their legs with pipe bombs, and listening to them die to fire sounded freaking AWESOME.  So I pre-ordered it.  (I was a console peasant back then)Let's just say it ruined my life in a very, very bad *ahem* good way..By the time Left 4 Dead 2 was announced in 2009, I had already skipped school so many times continuing was probably pointless.  I hadn't seen my family more than for dinners in months and oh god was it so good. (I'm regretting it now, don't worry.)  So I pre-ordered it again.  (PEASANT.  ;_;)Well yet again I lost my life.  Left 4 Dead probably was the cause of me dropping out of school twice.  And you know, the xbox community (this is back when there were people actually playing) actually wasn't half bad, or so I thought.BOOM.  I have a computer.  Got both the games.  Didn't play 1 much, as I've already played way too much of it.  Left 4 dead 2 Scavenge mode was my absolute favorite on xbox, and now on PC even more so.  Versus I didn't want to get into, as in Left 4 Dead 1 I played way too much of it and got burnt out.  I learned so many new things and tricks that you just couldn't possibly do on a controller.  I met new friends, and with the lovely (xx hours in the last 2 weeks) tracker, I stopped playing so frickin' much.  (okay, sometimes.) The community here, even if it is filled with a bunch of cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, is obviously, better.  I definitely recommend this game.   If you're looking for a good zombie game to play, this one is great.  It's so simple, yet there is always room for improvement.  I doubt many people don't own it these days, as its always on frickin' sell.  If you don't have it, buy it already.Just a few tips:Learn the infected classes.  Like how the hunter needs to crouch before he can pounce in some way or another (more complicated moves are saved for later), and other stuff having to do with the infected.This game is team based.  Your teammates matter.  If your teammates are struggling, help them, unless you are absolutely better off going alone (I can only think of a few scenarios).  If your teammates can't cover you and you're 'MLG PRO B@$$' don't be all 'g3t on my l3v37 n00b', switch freaking places with them.  That's your only hope.  You don't go solo here. Same with infected.  Don't go solo.  Unless you're amazing and its a death charge, just don't.  You time your attacks accordingly, and work together to achieve the best results.Remember, all of the best teams you will ever run into in Left 4 Dead 2 certaintly know that working together is essential.  They just do it better than us.Use a mic + headphones / headset at all times.  Most people will get very annoyed if they can hear your game through your microphone, and let me tell you, trying to play a team based game with a mute person is not fun.SHOOT ALL THE THINGS.Gameplay Modes:CampaignStart by playing Campaign, either Solo or with friends.  Learn the controls up and down, & attempt to get the general rhythm of playing as a Survivor.You can either play campaign solo with single player and computer controlled teammates, or you can play Co Op.  I strongly preferred Co Op, as single player can be boring.  It is much funner to play while you joke about with your friends.  We have a few difficulties, start from Easy and work your way up.  Or, screw it all and play expert for the lulz!  I know I did that a few times with some friends, and it was hilarious.SurvivalPlay Survival for fun sometimes, its frustrating as you WILL die, but play it with your friends, and it will help you learn how to play as a team.This gamemode is generally you and three other survivors duking it out on the map of your choice, against an endless horde of zombies and special infected.  The special infected are computer controlled.You can play this alone or with teammates, but it's pointless without teammates.  This gamemode is great not only for trying to achieve an amazing time and the pure fun of that (and rage), but also because it will help improve your team working skills.  This is important.VersusWhen you feel like you understand the Infected classes and you feel comfortable playing as a team.In this game mode two teams of four go head to head.  One starts as Survivor, one as Infected.  The general goal as an infected is to kill the other team as fast as you can while working together, or if you are on the Survivor side, to make it to the end with all of your teammates alive.  Each time a section of a map ends, you replay that map as the other class.  Whichever team has the most points at the end wins.If you can, get a few friends together for a large versus game, where you won't run into a bunch of cocky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who don't remember they were new once too.  Otherwise, ♥♥♥♥ em' and just try to hold your own in a versus game.  You may get kicked, but don't let it get you down.  It's okay to make mistakes, that's how we learn, that is how we all learned.  Some people just forget that little fact.ScavengeWhen you feel like you understand the Infected classes and you feel comfortable playing as a team.This game mode is like versus.  Except you play on one map, and one map only, for a number of rounds.  The point as the Survivors is to fill the generator on the map with gas cans, and the gas cans will be spread out across the map (easily visible, so no worries there).  On the other hand, the infected are trying to stop you.  They want you to either not get all the cans, or to get them all very, very slow.You switch back and forth and the winner of each round is determined by either who gets the most cans, or if it's a tie, whichever team got them all the quickest.Ahh, the game mode that sucked me in and took my life from me.  Scavenge is really fun.  But be warned, a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s chill in this gamemode.  Brush yo' shoulder off.MutationsWhenever.Fun gamemodes that you can and should play with your friends.  You can play them alone too, though.  I haven't played them all so I don't think I can accurately portray them, but they are fun.Realism & Realism VersusRealism is campaign but on crack.  You can't see each other through walls anymore, you're basically relying on each other to stick together.  Other aspects of the gameplay are hard too, like zombies taking more damage.  Great team building gamemode.Realism Versus is basically versus with realism thrown in it ^ (read above)

content:
Posted: March 29
												This game is honestly a classic and deserves to be in every single persons steam library. Whether it be because of the teamwork based gameplay, the extensive (and i mean, holy♥♥♥♥♥♥huge) mod list for this game, or the generally pretty helpful community, this game does it all. I purchased it on sale when it was only 5 dollars but it is easily worth buying even at the price it is at now. The first game i was in was a survival mode somewhat like Call of Duty Zombies except with no in between round wait time, some pretty chill dudes were explaining to the lobby how to get into a glitch that lets you survive longer (yes it is an old game, there are LOTS of glitches). They were helpful and definitely not rude, although i am sure as i play this longer i will run into a few rude people. Ive read reviews and they made me hesitant to purchase, some saying the community is toxic and will kick you for even a small mistake and stuff like that. Anyway, im sure someone will start b1tching, "you only have a few hours you havent even played it yet" and yeah, theyre right. On pc i barely have time logged into this game. This game was also on xbox 360, which i played extensively for hours on end. Same game, just a different platform. Anyway, it is a pretty cool game and thanks to the huuuuuge mod catalog, this game has near infinite playability. Sure, it might not be for everyone but i think this is a game most people would definitely enjoy. Buy it and give it a shot! Also, add me if youre down to play it cause itd be cool to have a few friends to play with. Its a game that requires a lot of teamwork and communication, especially on the higher difficulty levels.

content:
Posted: March 20
 Best Ways to Get Rid of Zombies  Anti-zombie arsenalGuns. Of course. Whenever you see a zombie movie, guns are the weapon of choice. And I use the term “guns” loosely. From a 9mm to a harpoon to a grenade launcher to a slingshot loaded with cherry bombs, guns can be a fun and effective way to get rid of zombies. Use them for target practice, set up sharp-shooting contests, or engage in zombie hunting escapades. It’s a fun outdoor activity for the whole family!Shovel. It’s good for digging, but more importantly, it’s good for whacking zombies. It can also be used for beheading. Y’know, removing the head and destroying the brain? Other than zombie whacking, shovels can be used for zombie poking, zombie prodding, zombie battering, and zombie dismemberment. You can find them in most garages, they fit into the back of any old pickup, and you can even use that shovel in your garden after the crash of civilization. Amazon has a fine selection, like this Ames True Temper beauty.Ax. For those preferring a more hands-on eradication of zombies, consider the ax. Exercise those upper body muscles and get a good cardio workout with each swing and hack. Use your ax to remove the head or destroy the brain. Or simply immobilize the zombie threat by removing its limbs. Use the ax to cut down trees to create a fence for a zombie fight ring. Invite your friends. Think of the entertainment value! Best Ways to Get Rid of ZombiesRemove the head or destroy the brain to get rid of zombies. This is the most basic principle of destroying the ravaging zombie horde. It relies on the assumption that the infected zombie brain sends brain-eating messages to the zombie body. Sever this connection between zombified brain and undead body and you are left with the simply dead instead of the undead. Without the motor skills or motivation to devour brains, the zombie becomes indistinguishable from any old corpse lying around. Use whatever means you have at hand. Then consider composting the remains for your garden. Though soylent zombie is not recommended as it may spread the zombie virus. And taste terrible.Chainsaws can get rid of zombies. If it’s good enough for Bruce Campbell as Ash in Evil Dead, it’s good enough for you! Perhaps this most classic method of zombie destruction and removal is what’s best for you. This will not only remove the head or destroy the brain, but can also disembowel, de-limb, quarter, massacre, destruct, and generally discombobulate zombies. Two drawbacks with this method include the splatter zone and the chainsaw wielder’s close proximity to zombie teeth. This method is best used on slower moving zombies with poor motor skills. And don’t forget to take along your raincoat.A tiger pit can help you get rid of zombies. This is an oldie but a goodie. Using the shovel from your anti-zombie arsenal, dig a deep pit. Think grave-deep, at least. Then, using your anti-zombie ax, fashion some grotesque wooden spikes out of some local trees or remnants of old wood picket fences. Securely embed the spikes at the bottom of the pit. Cover the hole with a sheet or tarp or any other pliable surface. Cover that surface with leaves. Consider using a decoy, such as an irritating in-law for bait, and you have yourself a genuine pit of doom for any wandering zombies.Get rid of zombies using a wood chipper. If perhaps your zombie type is of the slow-moving and easily tricked variety, a wood chipper is an excellent way to remove yourself of these unwanted zombies. Consider a type of tiger-pit strategy with perhaps a human or another zombie as bait. Using a wood chipper will not only remove the head or destroy the brain of zombies with unadulterated gusto, zombie chunks may yet prove a useful source of natural fertilizer, or even a natural biofuel. Just don’t forget your safety goggles.Wait for the zombies to decay. This method relies heavily on the type of zombie infestation that you have. This will not work on every kind of the undead. But it may be that the type of zombie around your neighborhood doesn’t have a very long shelf-life. If your zombies are the type that cannot regenerate or repair their own tissue, then hot-dang, all you have to do is wait it out! Exposure to the elements will wreak havoc upon undead tissue. And as they begin to decay, their ability to acquire brains from human beings also decays. Soon these ferocious brain seekers will only be piles of goo, and your life can once again return to normal. Things to avoidFire. While fire may seem to be a natural, cheap, and easy solution to your zombie infestation, I assure you that fire is most likely not the answer. You know how those zombies are, always getting into everything. Curious little creatures they are. Now, can you picture those curious little biters on fire?Nuclear arms. Nukes. Good for killin’ the whales. Bad for killin’ the zombies. Imagine a bunch of brain-crazy, undead cannibals hell bent on eating you. Now imagine that they’re radioactive to boot. You get where I’m going with this. So, unless you’re into killing whales, avoid the nukes.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												While Left 4 Dead 2 had a rocky start, Valve greatly improved the quality of the game after release. In almost every way L4D2 replicates it's predecessor and surpasses it at the same time.L4D2 unlike it's predecessor has maps that take place during the day. It features more special infected that require constant movement and cover. And it features melee weapons that add an entirely new dynamic to gameplay. All of these features are woven very well with the carried over elements from L4D1. The game still requires players stick together inorder to avoid being pounced by legions of undead and it keeps the frantic fast paced atmosphere. Alongside that, the game's versus mode adds a great deal of strategy to the gameplay. And lastly it's survival mode allows players to test their skills and provide a nice healthy amount of competition amongst each other.I'd go as far as to say L4D2 now is one of Valve's best attempts at multiplayer games on the Source engine. Harder, Faster, Better and Stronger in almost every way.

number of helpful: 26 of 39 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												Many people love L4D2, following the incredible success of L4D. Personally, I think this game is a heap of♥♥♥♥♥♥/b> - and I love just about every other Valve game.Technically and graphically, it is better than L4D, and unfortunately, that's the only part it is better. In everything else, it stinks.Gone is the atmosphere, the friendly rivalry between Louis and Francis, the grainy 70's film effect (seriously, wtf were you thinking), dark brooding cityscapes, and the witty repartee between all four members.Instead, you get four unlikeable characters that spend more time whining and ♥♥♥♥♥ing at each other, bright sunny days in New Orleans, and near constant waves of zombies.In fact, that is the main thing that irks me about the sequel. In the first one, if you had a strong member of the team, there was a fair chance they could pull the the rest of the team through, which made for some hectic, but fun, gameplay.In L4D2, there is no chance of that. The waves are too relentless and the specials spawn far too frequently, so if the team is a little disorganised, you're ♥♥♥♥ed with a capital F.Once the game decides it is going to target you, that's it until you either run of medkits or the team gets tired of trying to protect you. More often that not, you're spawning back at the safehouse, because one player got boomed, jockeyed and then incapped in the spitter goo. Cue ragequitting from less invested members of the team. The fun factor just shines through at that point (/sarcasm)I've tried hard to like this game, really I have. God knows I've put enough hours into it, but I just can't bring myself to like it in any way shape or form. In fact, I've gone from trying to like it to hating it, and have completely removed it off my PC. If I could delete it from my Steam library, I would.L4D may have had it's flaws, but it certainly had atmosphere and characters you could warm to, and my final verdict is that L4D2 does not hold a candle to it.To sum it up - in the first game, you felt like you were all fighting against hordes of zombies. In the second one, it feels like you are fighting everything in the game - zombies, weather, terrain - some maps are just a slow grindingly weary slog from start to finish.It's cheap enough to pick up for a bit of fun, and you might like it, but I seriously can't recommend it when the preceding game was far FAR superior in gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												I originally got this game because a friend convinced me to. I was hesitant because it was a zombie game and I didn't handle well in the Call of Duty: Nazi Zombies game. After I bought it, I noticed very quickly that this game makes friends FAST! It promotes teamwork between 4 players known as survivors, as they try to make it to the CEDA extraction point.Specifically, this story follows Nick, Ellis, Coach, and Rochelle. Each character has a personality of their own, unlike Gordon Freeman or Chell from other Valve games. Nick was a gambler, according to the commentary, he looted his white suit to survive in style. He often sounds stern, and serious about their situation. As in Dark Carnival he says in response to Coach and Ellis's excitement, "Now we can die there as adults."Ellis is a child at heart, and he is known as the mechanic of the group. If the player stays in the safehouses long enough, Ellis will tell a tale from his pre-apocolyptic life with his friend Keith. He is very happy about anything, and no he's not crazy, he still hates zombies. He's a native to Georgia which is where the story takes place.Coach is sort of a mix between Ellis and Nick, he is serious at times and at other times, like in Dark Carnival, he can be quite happy. I actually don't know much about his character, but I do know that he also is native to Georgia.Rochelle is commonly known by the community as the one with the annoying laugh. She is caring towards Ellis and often refers to him as "sweety" when he trails off on one of his stories. I don't know much about her either, but she is mainly for the girl gamers to play as.This game also brings the four together with the original four survivors Bill, Francis, Louis, and Zoey. This happens in The Passing. The game also is appealing because it adds L4D1 campaigns too, so you've got plenty of levels to entertain yourself. The important thing is that the game has amazing replay value! Just beating the levels isn't enough to wear out this game! You also can't forget the workshop, which adds campaigns, survivors, weapons, and zombies that can change the game in dramtic ways!

												I simply can not write this review without saying one thing.Old but gold.Thats it.L4D series in general is an amazing zombie killing, non stop action endorsing first-person shooter that is still being played to this date.Now I have played a lot of both games off steam back in the day and the biggest fun factor is getting your friends and you all group up as you try to survive  the butchering hordes that are chasing you. Singleplayer aspect of the gameThe gameplay is simple to understand, reach the safe house or get absolutely slaughtered.Throughout your campaign you will meet many survivors who have fallen to the green flu.Raging from the common infected,to the special infected and up to a mini boss a tank.There are in total 6 special infected,with the 7th one being the tank and a not so commonly found witch.The campaigns are not that difficult to complete,in fact after a couple of hours you'll be rushing trough them like a bowling ball trough pins.Now thats for the singleplayer. Multiplayer aspect of the game Multiplayer is currently experiencing a bit of a bad time.Not just now but for years.And as much as I love this game and trust me I do, I cannot encourage you to get it if youre aiming to play with random people.If youre gonna play it with your friends then of course get it right away.But If you get it to play multiplayer with randoms you will be kinda disappointed.I've seen people being kicked in versus mode for the smallest things,even being kicked for having a name that someone doesnt like.Random kicks are always being voted and it seems to never stop.I love this game but some people take the multiplayer down to the drain with such acts.My final verdict for L4D2 is 8/10.If you're gonna play it with some friends,get it right away.Hell even if you wanna play with randoms get it.But keep in mind what I said.Thank you for your time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Left 4 Dead 2 is a cooperative first-person shooter and the sequel to Left 4 Dead.The sequel picks up one week after the events of the first game where The Infection has spread to the southern United States. Left 4 Dead 2 introduces new weapons, melee weapons and new items. There is a new cast of human Survivors, which include: Coach, a portly high-school football coach with a bad knee; Nick, a rude and cynical gambler and con artist;Rochelle, a low-level production assistant reporting on the evacuation for a local television station; and Ellis, a friendly mechanic.The game also introduces three new Special Infected: The Charger, The Spitter and The Jockey.Left 4 Dead 2 currently has thirteen campaigns playable in all gameplay modes, six of which are from the original Left 4 Dead. The game has 4 different game modes: Campaign, Versus, Survival and Scavenge.During Campaign, also known as Co-op, up to four players work together to try to reach the end of the campaign by fighting their way past large numbers of AI-controlled Infected. There are four difficulty levels: Easy, Normal, Advanced and Expert.Versus is the basic competitive mode for the Left 4 Dead series: two separate teams of four players take turns playing as the Survivors and the Infected competing for the most points.The point of Survival Mode is to hold out for the longest time, with times being saved and virtual medals being awarded for surviving for certain amounts of time.Scavenge is a competitive gameplay mode in Left 4 Dead 2. It is a round based game in which Survivors have a limited amount of time to find up to 21 gas cans to fuel up a generator (or car), while fighting against player-controlled Special Infected much like in a Versus game.As in the first game, each scenario is presented like a movie. At the start of the game there is a movie poster showing the cast. At the end the "credits" display the statistics for the game, like who killed the most zombies, who inflicted the most headshots and so on. The final credit shows how many zombies were killed in the making of the film and also the film is dedicated to the memory of those survivors who did not make it to safety.Every aspect of Left 4 Dead has been refined and tweaked to perfection. It has brilliant graphics and a nice cinematic feel. The new campaigns and unique game modes offer more variety and more longevity, while all the other additions and tweaks make the already great gameplay even more enjoyable. Even the AI has improved a little bit, and while they still aren't big on using pipe bombs or Molotovs and are prone to missteps, they seem to have a better grasp of tactics and will follow you a bit more closely. Still, Left 4 Dead 2 is best enjoyed with friends.It is an addictive and atmospheric game and it is in my opinion one of the best co-op games ever made.Sounds 9/10Graphics 9/10Gameplay 10/10Atmosphere 9/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Before posting this review, it thought: "hey, let's have a look to the negative comments to see wha- wait. What the hell is this?"People complain about it having bad graphics, crashing when starting, not being suited to be classified to survival, or horror, etc, etc. I mean, seriously.First of all, Left 4 Dead is an awesome game about TEAMWORK. Yes, teamwork. I see people complaining about being kicked from versus. Playtime: 1-2 hours. What do you expect when you don't know how to play properly? I'm not saying I'm a pro, but it's been blood and sweat to become decent at this game, running it on a crappy notebook, at 10-15 fps on hordes. You can do better than complaining on reviews. You could actually play the game. Learn how to share first-aids, pills, adrenalines, use defibs, when to use stuff. That's only learned by playing campaings, watching gameplays and so on.Secondly, before buying a game, the best you can do is find a torrent and download it; watch gameplays on YouTube, read critics on the internet, and then try it on your own. If you like it, buy it. If you don't like it, don't. If you got it free, then don't complain unless it's useful. There are lots of ways to try a game before buying it. Lastly, people complain about online players being rude and mostly rage quitters. This is not completely true. However, I do agree that the community is not as warming and welcoming as it used to be. This is because the amount of players playing it has increased considerably, leading to people who cannot handle losing, people who consider themselves gods of L4D2, etc. Is this only their fault, though? I highly doubt it. People who complain about others mistreating them, usually tend to hide the fact that it might also be their fault. It's not hard to say "could anyone help me, I'm new on this game". It's not hard to make friends on this game. I have made lots of them playing versus, and my friends too. It's about the attitude towards how you behave against others.L4D2 is a great game. Enjoyable. A bit repetitive. But what game isn't after playing it for 80+ hours. Tell me RPGs are not about killing monsters over and over again, or others FPS are about killing guys, looting stuff, etc. Think before posting a review. Is it your game crashing? There are forums where you can post your problem. Is it that you didn't like it because of unknown reasons? Give good reasons stating the facts that make it bad. But most important, change your attitude towards the game, and online players. I'm not speaking only for newcomers, but also for those so-called pros who mistreat newcomers on versus.

And this is the fastest *glitched* votekicking and insulting simulator I ever saw.And a game joke:- Why headshoots don't work in L4D2?- Because no one L4D2 user has any brain.TL;DR:PUBLIC MULTIPLAYER: TROLLS&ID#OTS, RAGEQUITS, GLITCHERS, THEY TEAMKILL YOU *RIGHT BEFORE* CAMPAIGN ENDS, THEY KICK&BLAME YOU FOR EVERYTHING: LOOSING, LESS HOURS, WINNING(!). HIT/MISS IS A GLITCHABLE PING/LERP-RELATED S##T. QUICKPLAY OFTEN JOINS PAY-TO-WIN/CHEAT/R#PE SERVERS. SINGLE-PLAYER IS BORING AFTER FIRST FINISHED EXPERT! 7+Y.O. GRAPHICS! CAM IS ALWAYS INSIDE SOMEONE!In my opinion you should AVOID Left 4 Dead 2(1) unless it's cost equals to ZERO, because this is the exact amount of joy the public multiplayer will give you!You WILL feel like an overdue sh#t! Check health insurance before buying that game! CatMario is less frustrating than public multi- there!Community says you should NEVER join multiplayer versus modes (versus/realism versus/scavenge) without thousands hours of experience... but you can get good experience as SI ONLY BY PLAYING MULTIPLAYER VERSUS MODES... So this is the classic dead end.This game is 7 years old. You will meet members with 7 years of experience. Many of them simply started to stink or went crazy...My ex-friend offered me L4D1 for free as a legal Steam gift. I refused. I did not wanted to join another community horror.Best part is when 3 players got incapped and you are the only who can help them. You are going to help them, but there is a hunter chasing you, so you fight him first. And you killed him and start running to help them... And THIS is the moment when you will be usually votekicked for not giving an IMPOSSIBLE INSTANT help for 3 d#mb and thankless id##ts... But when you ignore the hunter, try to instantly help them and get catched by hunter, you will be kicked too...Even when you have hundreds/thousands hours of experience and have been playing a long and enjoyable scavenge match with friends in public game, then often 1 or 2 id#ots join your team and start votekicking or TKing you. Public games are the f-g cancer there.You can start your own localhost server and this can protect you somewhat against kicks. But you need a really good Internet connection. Public IP is recommended. Many people leave localhost or sometimes try to DDoS/hack your PC.Summing up, multiplayer community contains:- trolls who will team-kill you and rage;- newbies who rage after the first tiny failure;- toxic pros who will votekick you after the first tiny failure... even if it was their failure...;- toxic id#ots who will kick you for not being a wizard and slave (well... if you are a wizard and slave, you are kicked anyway);- id##ts who will votekick or kill you right before the campaign ends;- enhanced lame-pros on official servers who do wall-hack, bbox-glitch, grab & throw 14455 cans per second and are uncatchable by special infecteds (no, those players will NOT be VAC-banned, they will kick you);- id##ts who join public games and slash all the joy of users playing there just because;- fake-females, catfishes, phishers, game vulnerability exploiters and slowhacking game servers;- strange person who can remember you and DDoS every game server you join for the next year (all players are disconnected during DDoS);- at least one id##t from my country who yells "kick f-g noobs!" via mic and kicks EVERYONE!You may be kicked for:- being dead before others;- when someone other was killed before you;- doing everything right while votekicker has no idea why you did what you did;- not helping a person;- helping a person;- going left for 12.4 seconds instead of 12 seconds;- not being a wizard and slave;- not using the mic;- using the mic;- not having >5000 hours of gameplay;- having ping >80ms;- not catching uncatchable player;- not using key binds or scripts;- when they wanna friend instead of you right now;- when votekicker is an id#ot.During sales some trolls set up scavenge servers with unplayable maps for noobs (scavenge with invisible walls, only waste of time).Some toxic "pros" join PUBLIC in 2 and kick EVERY other player. Saw it many times.Hit/miss IS ping related.And the VERY BAD thing is that Valve did IMHO a GOOD JOB and made the game WELL with reasonable multiplayer tools. And I am REALLY SAD to make a negative review. I even got the game for free during the event, so I should be happy... Maybe I should be happy, but after 1000+ hours I am unable to recommend this game to newbies... It was my only multiplayer game so I was retrying very often, but on any versus it is usually one big piece of mental horror...Valve even added achievements for people who help newbies, but the community never changes...After 1k hours I wanted to maximize my EXPERT achievements AND I DID IT... by playing SINGLE-PLAYER ALONE WITH THOSE "BAD" BOTS... because multiplayer users usually raged, TKed, votekicked or went crazy before the campaign ended (or even started)... and I did this alone successfully without any ill stress, even if it was 4 times harder to complete the map (no rescue closets, bots do NOT carry fuel cans). No cheats/hacks. Some retires needed, but it was doable and enjoyable after finishing!On the contrary, I bought OTHER AAA game and started Team Deadmatch multiplayer after only 15 minutes of experience (including the time of messing with GFX settings). And... no one blamed others for being a noob with rank 1 (they had ranks like 25, 60), no one raged, no one votekicked... And we even won. And it was joyful. I believe something like that is impossible with L4D2.So if you really wanna try L4D2, there are my pro-tips:DO PLAY versus and scavenge after some SOLO (single-player) play. Do NOT stick with solo play - it is the dead end.1. Find someone on public games who is weak (or has little hours) and is NOT a troll/i####t.2. Friend him. 3. Play with him in friends-only game.Repeat 1-3 to make bigger team.When you are voted without a valid reason and without any explanation, then block person who started the votekick.You are welcome.And if you like TR2013 for it's CASUAL/RANKED selector, L4D2 doesn't have it...Read about console commands that improve your security against exploits.Apply security commands BEFORE joining any multiplayer games.If you believe that experienced community help newbies, visit community forum and think again! For no reason.At all.I don't know what I did to deserve this...Originally posted by Vietcong Charlie (NVA):I would kick you just for giggles.In fact, I would probably make several alt accounts just kick you for more giggles.Originally posted by Acevy:The community for this game is probably worse than anything else I've ever playedOriginally posted by jari86:Don't like it or the community - get the f##k outta here. ... A true example of innovation done right in gaming.-Graphics: crisp, clean textues and environments. 720p and up.-Frame Rate: 60fps and up.-Sound: Audio is breathtaking, clear, and optimized.-Gameplay: Incredible. A simple system that's easy for first time players to learn, yet complex to offer late game masters something to calculate with. Balanced enemies, spawn rates, weapons, movements, HP system, and ammo capacity. Can be as challenging, easy, or unforgiving as you want. Well tailored to any and all players.-Level design: Environments are diverse and uniquely pathed to offer a different feel and strategy per level. Spawns and item placements are mostly randomized, yet still manages to make use of every corner of the maps. Direction and pace of play is linear, but never gets old or burdensome.-Multiplayer: Fast connections, great server support, one button in game press to check your signal strength. Local, dedicated, and undedicated server support.-Customization: Near everything can be modded to suit anything you can think up. Textures, sounds, maps, Ai, objectives, text.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 9, 2016
												So, it's time to write something about Left 4 Dead 2, I guess.Yes. Yes, I know this review comes late, but who cares, huh?Left 4 Dead 2 was one of the first games I bought on Steam and still remains one of my favourites because of it's diversity and the fun you can have when playing with friends. It's a First-Person-Survival-Shooter where you have to fight your way through various maps and chapters, whilest semi-brutally slaughtering tons and tons of zombies.If you plan to buy this game, make sure your friends do own it too, otherwise you will only have half as much fun as possible.Now on to the game design:The overall design gets a 8/10 from me.The weapons are well rounded, have a game-fitting visual design and are fun to play.The zombies are great. Normal zombies aren't a great threat, if they do not appear in big hordes, like you would expect it. The special infected are tougher, but not impossible to beat and it just overall feels great to fight them.The map design is also fitting for a post-apocalyptic world, it's all in a more grey-ish style and seems rotten and abondoned.The game mechanics:Survival-Slaughter. It's as simple as that. Find basic weapons at the beginning, progress through the linear chapters and fight, fight, fight. I personally would've enjoyed it even more, if the game would've let more opportunities for alternative ways open, or the ways would've been harder to find, but it was okay and I guess I spent more time hindering my friends than actually fighting.The best part about the game is the mod- and Steam-Workshop-support, you can make a completely different game. Your zombies can be Stormtroopers, Aliens or you could even let out your hate of bronies on them! You can add different sounds, weapon skins, maps, character models, everything you can imagine to mod can be modded.So - All-in-all:Gameplay: 8/10Design: 8/10Diversity: 9/10Fun-Factor: 9/10A great game and definately worth checking out. Have fun slaughtering with your friends!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												Even though it's an old teamwork-oriented game, it still is so much fun to play on and has so many things to do; never gets boring if you have 2-3 friends to play together in versus games. Also, the custom campaigns from the workshop add a boost of entertaining and the scavenge on the rooftop from No Mercy map is very awesome. The plot is simple because all you need to do is to go from a safe house to another killing everything which is in your way. I spent on over 2k hours on and the price is worth it, that's why i highly suggest everyone who's interested in good content should try this.It has its ups and downs. You can basically meet all sorts of people in the community, nicer or less nicer, from where you can choose to play further. This is why it's very competitive. From time to time, you can experience minor bugs but they don't downgrade the experience.In conclusion, I give this game 10/10, one of the best old games out there!

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												Atrocious community. Ive met several pretty cool people, but Ive also met hundreds of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.The versus mode is the most popular online mode, and its fun, when you can get a balanced game going. This is almost impossible to accomplish, however. Im not sure how many versus games Ive played... maybe 100? Out of those, 2... TWO have been balanced games. Both those times my team lost point wise, but we all won because everyone had lots of fun. The remaining 98 have been total routes for one side the entire match. Even on the winning side, its just not very fun.Also, happen to not play with absolute perfection? You get vote kicked, despite you probably doing better than the other 3 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s your with.Happen TO play with absolute perfection, at least relative to your teammates? You get vote kicked anyway, because the 3 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s want ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ #4 to join their game and your holding up the spot.From what I gather the community has deteriorated over time. I wish I had gotten this when it was new. Unfortunately I didnt even know it had come out.Gameplay wise, the game could use some tweaking. There are several blatantly unbalanced "quirks" this game has, that detract from an otherwise balanced experienced. But overall its well done and fun to play.The game alone is enjoyably designed for the most part. Unfortunately this being a co-op centered game, the community brings down the games final rating by several notchs, since the community is integral to this games experience.Possibly recommended when on sale just to give it a try.

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												This updated review is directed to those considering buying this game at the time of a sale.If you have not checked my profile, you will see that I have more than 4,800 hours at the time of this review.  There is a good reason for that, I can tell you this game is fun for anyone who wants to shoot zombies/infected.  Unlike other zombie games, You get to actually play as the infected against player-controlled survivors and vice versa.  It is even more fun when playing with friends in against an equally-skilled opposing team. This game features and abundance of assorted games modes and mutations (which are sames modes but with varied tweaks) perfect for just about anyone.  If you are new, go to forums and find some new players such as yourself and add them as your friend.  Play with those friends in the campaign mode to learn the game and its infected.  Practice playing as the infected in Versus Survival mutation mode.BEWARE,  IF YOU JUMP straight into the Versus/Scavenge competitive modes before actually earning experience in a lot of campaign games, you will be met with a somewhat unwelcoming community that will vote kick you.  As with any game, you have to learn the basics before trying to go into the competitive (Versus/Scavenge) modes.  There is a good reason for this (despite the community having a bad reptuation), a infected team will exploit any weakness the other team has: be it a new player with inexperience, a slow-progressing person, or player with incomplete understanding about the game mechanics.  It is the fact that player infected can think tactically and combine their attacks whereas bot-controlled infected in campaign will go attack one-by-one but not all the time.As a new player, the vote kicking feature will seem like your worst enemy and will even turn you off and disregard this game (A lot of silly forum threads because of these reasons).  But after awhile, you will learn that this feature is necessary as it removes AFKs, Griefers (Teamkillers/glitchers), and inexperienced players (sadly).  Remember that there is no rank system in place and therefore you will be placed with veteran players easily in Versus.  Getting dominated quickly is no fun nor is it fun for your teammates.  Strangers in versus will rant on you for single mistake (which is wrong) but one mistake on infected can mean 400 easy points to the opposing survivor team.  Likewise one mistake can mean your entire survivor team falls and unable to aquire points. In campaign you can retry to complete the map but in Versus YOU DON'T.It would be great if you brought over experience from the xbox version of this game. BUT!! keep in mind, the standards of playing ARE MUCH higher here than on xbox.  I played xbox for the longest time before coming to pc, and I noticed one thing.  Survivors can aim a lot better than their xbox equilivents. So in xbox, the infected have the upper hand and are able to do damage even if attacking alone.  But in this PC version, attacking alone as infected will get you killed easily (you will be lucky to get close to a group bunched together).  Xbox only tranfers over: map layouts, item usage, and gameplay mechanics.Unlike Resident Evil games, you will have to work with your teammates to succeed here.  Remember this is a co-operative game, you are playing as normal survivor and NOT some superhuman charater like in Resident Evil or Dead Rising games.  You cannot LONE WOLF it in Competitive modes, (theres a mutation game mode for those kinds of players) As time passed, the game introduced the Workshop. This allows you to customized your game to whatever you want.  Add some mods, character skins, custom music, visuals, whatever. It changes the look of the game to what you want but only you will see it though.  Example: you can change the survivors to anime characters or change the infected look, etc.Finally, remember this game requires communication so I suggest you get a HEADSET or microphone but it is not really neccessary.  Play with friends and take time to learn the game.  Remember your version of ''Fun'' may not be the same as the your teammates so you can't just play the competitive modes and expect your team accept your shortcomings unless they are on your friends list.IGN Quote : "Ultimately, enjoyment derived from this game depends on you are playing with and how you are playing."....."this is very social minded game that really plays of human nature..."

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Short Review: This game is a highly overrated and generic zombie game that, in my eyes, is one of Valve's only failures. Not only does the game itself suck, the community is also quite awful. Go spend your money on some indie games or something.Long Review: Left 4 Dead 2. Although the critics and players rave about this game being one of the best zombie games on the market, it really isn't. Sure, there's lots of different areas to fight through, but they are all just retextured copies of the others. Get weapons, kill zombies, press E, kill zombies, get different weapons, kill zombies, kill more zombies, press E. That is how most of the levels work. There are also the levels where you collect x, bring to y, and hold E. Get weapons, kill zombies, pick up object, run past zombies, hold E. Rinse and repeat until you've beaten the level. Now that we've discussed the single player problems, let's move on to the multiplayer. The community sucks and expects you to know what each weapon is, what it does, and how to use it effectively as well as knowing each level like the back of your hand. You will be kicked if you don't have either 100 hours of play time or are quite skilled in everything I just listed. The game modes where you can play as the infected aren't fun either. The infected are difficult to use and are at a disadvantage when compared to the survivors. The only good thing about this game is the great integration of the Steam Workshop. You can download different music, new weapons textures, new levels, and more. In other words, buy this game if you want to be disappointed. Rating: 4.5/10

Posted: July 1, 2014
												My review for Left 4 Dead 2- I can say that this game, is one of the famous pioneer of zombie co-op game. While this is the sequel, but this game complete its predecessor.- Really fun to play with friends.- Can be modded. Definitely good feature here.- The enemies not really that frightening because first, the way they behave are funny, second, you got 3 more friends (or AI) have your back. Be careful though, don't let them swarm your team.- Not only normal zombies, but also unique special zombies with different abilities, and also uncommon normal zombies that have unique traits on them.- Different game mode to play. There's versus mode who can make you the special zombies, and have purpose to prevent the survivor from saving themselves. There's also more game mode like scavenger, survival, realism. You can even add more with mods.- A lot of choices of weapons. Additional melee weapons that makes this game better than its predecessor.8.7/10

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												If you don't have this game already, and like First Person Shooters... get it. It's sometimes on sale for only a few dollars, and on occasion has even been free for a weekend or Christmas.The best co-op game I've ever played, hands down. I spent nearly a thousand hours playing campaign mode before even dipping a toe into Versus or Scavenge game modes. These (competitive) multiplayer modes are very fun also, but be aware that you will be expected to have mastered the learning curve BEFORE jumping into these - your teammates will expect you to know the game already, and there's virtually no on-the-job training, so to speak. ;)L4D2 includes pretty much all the content of L4D1, and a bunch more besides - 4 new survivors, 3 new Special Infected, 5 new campaigns, new "uncommon infected" specific to these new campaigns, and new player-usable items in every category. Plus an add-on workshop to customize your game when it finally starts feeling stale. In terms of play hours per dollar spent, no other game I have EVER played comes close.So if you're wondering whether to get this game? Get it, especially if you can get it on sale. Even if you only play it a bit and put it aside for other things, you'll probably be glad you have it in your library to play with friends occasionally.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												Damn it, no, I can't. Even if I would want, I can't recommend L4D2 over L4D1. I'm gonna skip the community thing as often players are behaving like bunch of idiots even outside of game (vide forums etc.) so I think it doesn't worth any commentary as it won't save this game.Despite having more hours played in sequel, when I bought L4D1 I felt like I'm playing completely different game. In my opinion it's the L4D1 which looks like finished product, more polished, way less glitched and annoying with its gameplay mechanics. Everytime I turn on L4D2 I see idiotic Survivors animations, ugly flying pistols and unbellevable amount of melee weapons and SMGs, like game wanting to say „C'mon, don't pretend to be a hero, just take that axe and run like idiot – I'm gonna kill you anyway during next Crescendo Event if you won't drop your pistols”. I don't say L4D1 is easier – maybe sometimes it is, but I feel that thinking ain't necessary (and even welcome) in L4D2.Someone may say that I'm another L4D1 addict being mad at Valve because of L4D2 and porting older campaigns, but no, I can't be like that since I actually bought L4D1 after buying L4D2 (yes, I was that dumb) and while I feel L4D1 was worth my money, I think I wasted $$$ on L4D2. But I am mad at Valve as I think L4D2 is step back. And the saddest thing is that people moved anyway to then new and fresh game which is now practically as old as L4D1 which I prefer.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												If you're looking for a 1 sentence review, Even if this game was $100 or even $150 I would buy it, totally worth it.Without a doubt, the ABSOLUTE BEST coop (& zombie based) game I have ever played, & probably ever will play (probably until L4D3).I compare ALL other coop games to this game.I just keep coming back to L4D2 no matter what, even after years, I just love this game so much! Can't get enough of it.  I can't remember even a second where I wasn't bored with L4D2. This game is like my salvation, always there for me whenever I get bored, always ready to be awesome & fun.And you know the best part? Even if there was only the 5 basic maps, I would still play this game for years on end, it's just that much FUN.  (the game comes with more than 5 campaigns; 5 L4D2 original campaigns, 5 L4D campaigns, 2 cross-over campaigns & 1 Community campaign that was made Official due to it being super awesome)This game in phenominal in the way that you don't mind playing the same campaigns over & over again, every time it's a different experience.  And then of course there's the campaigns in the Workshop, that add so much more to the game & show cool new features too!If you want a game where you can play with friends, shoot zombies, have sht tons of fun, & with a little bit of tactics & smart play mixed in, this is the game you've been waiting for!

												Left 4 Dead perfected the co-op shooter, this expanded on it. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Interested in Zombie killing?  Looking to survive the apocalypse?  This first person shooter game maybe the key to all mankind.  The great thing about this game is the versatility as well as the variety of zombie attacks.  You can go from story line by yourself to with your friends or even with strangers.  There are various levels such as easy, normal, advanced and campaign.  But that's not all.  There are more game modes that will keep you interested!  Fight in multiplayer cooperative games such as survival to see how long you can last.  Best part about it, you never win... you always die!  Go more into depth with the game and become infected with your teammates and attack the other teams in versus or savenge.  What did you say? The game is too easy?  Try it out in realism.  This game mode does not give you help like glowing ammo or items.  They don't even tell you where your friends are.  Like in real life, you have to find where they are for yourself!With Mutations, you have a set of rules or variations of the game you play by... so if you are looking for a harder version of survival... Nightmare may be your answer... Want to shoot all zombies with a M60? No problem! Gibs fest will grant that.All these are fun and dandy, but the game wouldn't be the game that it is without 3rd party server hosts, dedicated and casual players as well as contributors to the steamworkshop where you can add more maps, skins and textures to your game by subscribing to the item so you have the newest updates for those items as well!. :)We long for a LFD3, but as the game continuously grow with players and mods from the workshop things can get quite... Interesting.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Left 4 Dead 2 is the Fps of choice to the gore hounds and the zombies lovers. The game itsef is not much like classic zombies where survival is the top priority, instead its more of a first person shooter, where landing your shots and have sharp senses will many times decide your fate. Getting infected is not a thing as the survivors in this game cannot turn. Zombies are so weak and so fragile, they there simply to slow you down. The real game is between the survivors and the special infected, mutated zombies variants, that use they multiple habilities to kill the survivors, and as they are the only ones that can be controled by humans, its a game of teamwork where the best team wins, in a 4vs4 versus game action. Now the worse part, the commnuity, you will always seem to find yourself stuck in the same situation, in a game with 3 other people in campaign where one of them starts to shoot everyone and leave, or in a versus game where your team joins and leaves, changing faster than you can keep up, while the other team is alwasy the same 4 people, just spamming, bringing up excuses evertime ur attack is sucessfull, and scream at you full force and CAPS LOCK with no regrets every swear word in the english dictionary everytime you survive they combined attack. You will be invited to a lot of Get owned groups and You suck, your mother will get insulted a lot in every language you can possibly imagine, and your teammates leaving you faster than rats in a sinking ship, but if, and only if, you luck out and find yourself great friends, you will enjoy this game for all its worth it.8/10 The best zombie game to play with friends, the worst game to play alone.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												One of the best co-op games out there.Left 4 Dead 2 uses a simple "zombie" theme with brand new characters, areas, and new special infected introduced. The graphics have imporved from the first game and the gore have been redesign so it is even more satisfying to shoot the zombies with hell of a lot more blood. There are also new special infected to make the maps more challanging. The new characters are really well designed and their dialogs are hilarous so the player interaction can be extreamly satisfactory if one finds a nice team to play with. This game is a remastered, improved Left 4 Dead. Some of the old game modes remain untoched, however Valve has added new ones like: Scavange, Mutations, and realism versus modes.This game is an imporved Left 4 Dead 1 game. 90/100Note: Don't buy left 4 dead 1 if you own left 4 dead 2. All the maps are included in Left 4 Dead 2.

												Love the multiplayer. Singleplayer is a bit difficult due to the terrible AI (who can't even throw molotovs, bile, or pipe bombs), but it is also fun when playing on a lower difficulty. But if you do get this game, get it for the multiplayer. Versus is tons of fun with friends, and I can say the same for the multiplayer campaign modes.  Everynow and then a mutation comes out, and with it, a lot of new fun as you adapt your playstyle to it. The gametypes are all unique, and if you value a good multiplayer experience, I would go and pick this game up.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												This game is a pure gem.Want coop? Want versus pvp? Want it to be more realistic (realism)? Want custom/addon content/maps (workshop+downloadable add maps)? Want lots diverse playmodes without sacrificing playability?Even if you don't want all that, there's nothing else that beats the mandatory teamplay, incremental ongoing learning ladder and all the diverse experiences that awaits in this game.Just get it (buy it), even if it's not for sale. Try everything, because all the different playmodes are that good (well thought out, designed and implemented)! Really!This is a game you can both play casually AND play over entire weekends. Just be sure to stretch your legs in between games. This is a game where it's relatively easy to find, create and join online games, and doesn't break the flow during a game unlike many other multiplayer online games.Be warned though: Start on the easier levels first (normal+). You'll learn more and learn enough to be helpful to games at Expert level later. If you get kicked, it's probably because you missed something and annoyed someone. Later, you may become friends with the more experienced players and appreciate the game even more deeply.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Interested in Zombie killing?  Looking to survive the apocalypse?  This first person shooter game maybe the key to all mankind.  The great thing about this game is the versatility as well as the variety of zombie attacks.  You can go from story line by yourself to with your friends or even with strangers.  There are various levels such as easy, normal, advanced and campaign.  But that's not all.  There are more game modes that will keep you interested!  Fight in multiplayer cooperative games such as survival to see how long you can last.  Best part about it, you never win... you always die!  Go more into depth with the game and become infected with your teammates and attack the other teams in versus or savenge.  What did you say? The game is too easy?  Try it out in realism.  This game mode does not give you help like glowing ammo or items.  They don't even tell you where your friends are.  Like in real life, you have to find where they are for yourself!With Mutations, you have a set of rules or variations of the game you play by... so if you are looking for a harder version of survival... Nightmare may be your answer... Want to shoot all zombies with a M60? No problem! Gibs fest will grant that.All these are fun and dandy, but the game wouldn't be the game that it is without 3rd party server hosts, dedicated and casual players as well as contributors to the steamworkshop where you can add more maps, skins and textures to your game by subscribing to the item so you have the newest updates for those items as well!. :)We long for a LFD3, but as the game continuously grow with players and mods from the workshop things can get quite... Interesting.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												First I thought this would just be another one of those zombie games, but then I realized that there is a lot more to it. There are not just zambees but a huge variety of them like, smokers, those monkey zombies, and these chargers who run right into you and have way too much health. This game is fun and I recommend it. This has to be one of my favorite Co op games. The second reason that makes this game so special is that this game requires a lot of teamwork. If someone has low health and they don't have a med kit, you should heal them. Or when people are about to fall from a ledge help them up and when people are lying on the ground, you should try to revive them. The more people you have, the quicker you get the job done. The only negatives to this game is L4D community. If you are AFK for a little bit, they kick you. Another example is that if you're trying to save yourself but this other person is being attacked and is low on health, they hate you for not helping them out. I've had an instance where a guy had to leave and then a new person replaced him. The other player in the game was being whiny and really wanted to kick him because he want the other player back. One of the biggest things that♥♥♥♥♥♥the hell out of me are the players in scavenge. They kick you almost all of the time if you are not helping the team. This is a few of the reasons why I hate Valve. But this rarely bothers me or anyone if you are good at this game. 8/10 And oh god is the Witch creepy!

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												The impression from 1st L4D was much stronger then from 2nd. 1st was gently scary and it was something new and exciting. 2nd version is an amplification of the first one, its features didn't excel the 1st part. The addition of few new common and special infected, melee weapons and guns and maps was not enough.For example, in movies Terminator 2 excelled Terminator 1. Aliens 2 excelled Alien. Half-life 2 excelled Half-life. But L4D2 didn't excel L4D. Don't like the idea with AI director that fills maps with wondering zombies. Makes all maps similar to each other, there is no difference when playing on one map or another except the layout and environment. Didn't like how the game becomes a chaos with thousands of sounds playing at the same time, when lots of zombies attack you, it becomes annoying. I just turn sound off at such moments. Daytime maps were interesting to try but it turns out that it's not so scary and not so cool as it was in first l4d.Despite these drawbacks, the game is very well made. Greatly optimized for slow PCs. Has nice maps and textures and sounds. Interesting SFX. Modding support. I'm not a zombie fan, but those who like zombie stuff will certainly love this game. I can recommend this game for everyone to try. But as for me I didn't like it.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												This is one of the best multiplayer, and possibly the best co-op experience I've had. I get to kill mounds upon mounds of zombies while teamed with my friends or stranger-teammates, and watch the blood fly on a memorable (enough) assortment of maps, all of this while getting to check out some very cool and not-very-experience-changing—but in a good way—mods. The AI also is well-built. Zombies act like they should, and the odd AI teammate can still be useful OR fun to kill! Especially when I'm not lagging, it's always fun to blow away and make a 'realistically violent' movie (if you know what I mean)! *10 burning zombies!*

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												There’s nothing more frustrating than having to depend on a loved one not to do something awful. In normal games you just have to believe in their skill, but Left 4 Dead 2 changes all of that with The Witch. She won’t hurt you if you don’t bother her. You could just walk past her, wave a bit, and be on your way. That is, assuming your friend isn’t a backstabbing pile of filth.You’re playing over Steam (obviously) and chatting like old drinking buddies when your friend suddenly goes quiet. "No," you plead with yourself as you hear the strained breathing of someone about to pull off a devious prank. Your friend's character slowly turns--it’s probably Coach--and raises his gun. The world is quiet. Then in one split second he fires at The Witch and your whole team is dead. The quiet returns, this time accompanied by your once-friend’s crazed laughter. They got you! Man what a jib. Yeah, screw you dude. I'm leaving you to die when I find the chopper.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ever wondered its time to join the 'zombpocalypse'? Left 4 Dead 2 is the best place for you. Four survivors with an arsenal of weapon ranging from chainsaw to M60 and lots and lots of Infected trying to hunt you down. L4D2 picks up where the first game left off, only with new survivors to hunt and be hunted. The short story of the game is spread through 5 chapters (although it was expanded with DLC campaigns). It is not overtly complicated and deep, but it can be suspected for a game of this nature and fairly this is not the most important part of this game. On normal settings the campaign can be completed around 4 hours or so, if you have access to the DLC campaigns it will extend the fun to 6-7 hours. Amping up the difficulty will increase the challenge and frustration originating from the retries you have to take to complete the chapters. While the story is not the richest out there, the game features some amazing voice over and writing. The characters are funny, witty and believable -- in the world of the game of course.When you (if you at all) breeze through the campaign with bots this is when the real fun begins. Online multiplayer is its name. Simply, this game is meant to be played with other humans. First of all, the AI is not horrible, bud it is bad enough that you will be constantly ripping out your hair while playing the game SP (especially on harder difficulties) Not to mention the Infected AI is much better. Second, the shooting is at its best when you are surrounded with real humans trying to help you survive or chasing you as Infected. Yes, there are game modes (Versus, Scavange, etc.) where you can show your skills as a Spitter, Charger or any type of Special Infected.The challenges will just never end with this game. You can play different MP modes like Versus or the newly introduced Scavange (collecting cans and filling up the generator while the Infected are trying to stop you). Or if you want you can just play the campaigns again with human help. If you are tired you can jump on community servers or try the endless number of easy-to-use mods created for the game by the community.Here we are again. Valve have proved again that they are indeed the masters of Multiplayer Madness. After hits like Counter Strike, Team Fortress we have the upcoming wave of games like the L4D2 series and DotA 2. While the SP mode is not much engaging and falls short of expectations and you may not care about the characters in the end, if you ever want to just jump in and oppose the endless hordes of zombies while having super fun, this is the ultimate and most definite place to start.Rating: 85/100; Replay Value: 5/5; To Beat: 6 hours (SP - with the campaign DLCs); Played on: normal.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Product received for free
												MINIMALISTIC REVIEWPros:- Fast-paced gameplay- Variety of weapons, attachments and bullet customization (eg; fire bullets, frag bullets, etc.).- UI and HUD is simple and understandable.- Story is well-organized and well-relayed (if the players do put attention on the story)- Melee weapons are introduced.- L4D game is combined to this game with a bonus top-rated community map featured on the game.- Variety of zombies and also the special common infected (eg; riot zombie, hazmat zombie).- Epic and challenging map and level designs.- Tutorials are user-friendly.- Features a band that KINDA existed (Midnight Riders!!!! WHOOO!!)- Music blends perfectly on the environment.- New systems have been added to the game that were not available on L4D (eg; witch's critical hit, etc.)- Characters are great and accomodated to the post-apocalyptic scenario.- No DLCs. Just pure fun.- Mods are welcomed (have your own style of the apocalypse).- YOU CAN BE THE INFECTED! Now that is fun.- Can be played with potato PCs.Cons:- Item physics are wobbling and act like light plastic (most especially the gas cans).- AI Survivors were designed to just shoot and pick up items (ammunitions to be specific). They are not designed to interact with certain objects given by the map.- Some weapons that are available at the game files are not accessible in the game (eg; AWP).RATING: 9/10 would shoot alarmed cars again.

												The most fun online multiplayer/coop FPS game I have ever played, it just never gets old or boring!The zombie apocalypse atmosphere is really well made and realistic and the special zombies add more tension to it. Graphics and soundtrack are great and fitting as well and the whole weapon system (1 big + 1 small or melee one can be carried, plus bombs, whereas the variety is not huge, but big enough) and ability to share medkits amongst the team add more realism to it.Many gaming modes are included too, aside from the standard campaign one, making the game a complete immersive experience.Teamwork is everything in this game if you want to survive, so it is also a good chance to meet new people!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2010
												Left 4 dead 2 is one of the most interactive co-op game I've ever played. This game will appeal to others who are looking for competitive, fun, and intense gameplay. Feel the wrath of hundred and hundred of zombies launching themselves at your throats. Don't stop for one sec for a Smoker to bind you with it's tongue. Don't stay in a open spot for a Hunter to claw you to death. Don't seperate from your teammates, you'll find yourself at the mercy of an Jockey. Zombies aren't your only enemies, watch your feet for acid that burns like no others from the mouth of an Spitter. Zombies are not noticing you? Then bathe in the bile of a Boomer to show a horde of zombies how good you looked......to eat. Narrow areas are the Charger's favorite spot to squash you into pancakes. She may be crying, but once the Witch is startled, you're in for a world of hurt, hope you have health insurance. Rarely appears, the Tank is the boss of zombies. He's one badass that will put your lights out.
